fields.physical_description: This photograph shows the building  popularly known as the  Diwan-i-Khass or Hall of private audience at Fatehpur Sikri. On the left hand side are the buildings known as the Ankh Michauli and Daulat Khana. There are four people in the foreground to give a sense of scale.
fields.dimensions: Length: 28 cm photograph, Height: 22.5 cm photograph, Length: 33 cm mount, Height: 26.7 cm mount
fields.title: The Dewan-i-Kass, or Hall of Audience, Futtehpore Sikri
fields.materials_techniques: Albumen print from a wet collodion negative

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.marks: Signature and negative number in bottom right hand side.
fields.public_access_description:
The main building on the right-hand side in this photograph is popularly known as the Diwan-i-Khass or Hall of Private Audience. It is in Fatehpur Sikri, a city built by the Emperor Akbar (ruled 1556-1605). On the left-hand side are the buildings known as the Ankh Michauli and Daulat Khana. The people in the foreground give a sense of the scale of the buildings.

The British photographer Samuel Bourne lived and worked in India between 1862 and 1869. During this time he toured the Himalayas and travelled through the subcontinent, photographing its landscape, architecture and historical sites. He set up a studio in Simla with Charles Shepherd and sold his prints sold to an eager public both in India and Britain.
fields.bibliography:
Asher, C, B, Architecture of Mughal India, The New Cambridhe History of India, , CUP, 1992
Rizve, S.A & Flynn, V.N, Fathpur Sikri, 1975
Archaeological Survey of India, Fatehpur Sikri, New Delhi, 2002
Alfieri, B.M, Islamic Architecture of the Indian Subcontinent, London 2000,
fields.history_note:
This photograph was initially part of the photographic collection held in the National Art Library. The markings on the mount are an indication of the history of the object, its movement through the museum and the way it is categorised.
The mount is green and has a lable with the title on the right hand side.

Historical significance: Like many of the buildings at Fatehpur Sikri, the building on the right has over the years been ascribed different functions. Inside it has an intricately carved  central pillar which is topped by an elaborate capital which supports a circular platform. This is linked by four bridges to the corners of the room. This central feature dominates the building and is the source of the various functions ascribed to the structure. Commonly known as the Diwan-i-Khass, the hall of private audience, Akbar would have sat high up on the circular platform and addressed his ministers down below. Rizvi believes that the building could have been a jewel house where the emperor sat on the platform and inspected his storehouse of gems down below. Nath takes the view that the building is a symbolic representation of Akbar’s belief in the cult of the sun. 

However, because of the difficulty/impracticalities  of actually sitting on the platform – a small cramped space and having to turn round to see people behind you, it is now thought that this building cannot be the Diwan-i-Khass. 

On the left hand side are the buildings popularly known as the Ankh Michauli and the ‘Astrologer’s Seat’. The Ankh Michauli (blind man’s buff house) is the larger building at the back and is romantically described as the place where Akbar played hide and seek with the women of his harem. Nath  believes it to be the Diwan-I-Khass or hall of private audience while Rizvi states that it is the Treasury of gold and silver. 

In front of this is a kiosk which four pillars and elaborately carved brackets. Popular tradition has ascribed it the function of the ‘Astrologer’s Seat’, but according to Rizvi it is likely to be the place where Akbar or his principle treasurer sat and distributed coins to subordinate officers or to the poor. 

The photograph shows damage to the eaves  of both buildings.
